newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Pasqua backs new referendum on Europe.
newsitem.headline: France's Pasqua backs new referendum on Europe.

text.p: Conservative former interior minister Charles Pasqua appealed on Sunday for a new referendum on European unity as a way to promote traditional French values like patriotism and counter the far-right National Front.

"It does not seem possible to me that we can move to a new phase of (European) construction without consulting the French people," said Pasqua, who opposed the Maastricht treaty on European union when French voters narrowly approved it in a 1992 referendum.

Pasqua, a member of French President Jacques Chirac's Gaullist RPR, said in an interview on RTL radio that French politics was divided over whether to abandon or retain traditional French republican values.

He said mainstream parties like his RPR had given up on such values as patriotism and nationalism, leaving the field to Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front, which has enjoyed a recent surge in popularity a year ahead of 1998 general elections.
"The problem is not the National Front. It is the inability of our political parties -- those which are governing and those which have governed -- to solve the French people's problems," he said.
"If you want to block extremist movements, you must not provide them with exclusive access to the ideas that used to belong to the major parties," he said.
Pasqua has been organising a campaign to convince the RPR to return to what he sees as its traditional values.
His "France of Tomorrow" association sponsored a colloquium on the topic on Sunday. But he denied he was trying to split the party in two.
"There is no Gaullist party today," he said. If there was one, the National Front would have only five to seven percent of the vote."
Le Pen won 15 percent of the vote in the 1995 presidential election.

Pasqua was a longtime backer of Chirac, but turned his back on his old friend during the 1995 campaign and endorsed the unsuccessful candidacy of rival Gaullist and then-prime minister Edouard Balladur.
